24.text: To all. How does your idea or ideas you support acknowledge, accommodate and enhance San Diego's diverse population? This area is teeming with people of color, and is part of the distinctly negative gentrifiying force affecting people of color. How are these communities engaged in this process? How will they benefit from this project-focus and force? What will they celebrate when they go home at night about their experience from this area? This note will likely ring a tiny bell in many that will be drowned out by the few in power.  But if we don't respect this perspective,  and decisively move from it,  then we are part of the community-bulldozing force I and I hope many others want no part of enriching.

24.text: To all. How does your idea or ideas you support acknowledge, accommodate and enhance San Diego's diverse population? This area is teeming with people of color, and is part of the distinctly negative gentrifiying force affecting people of color. How are these communities engaged in this process? How will they benefit from this project-focus and force? What will they celebrate when they go home at night about their experience from this area? This note will likely ring a tiny bell in many that will be drowned out by the few in power.  But if we don't respect this perspective,  and decisively move from it,  then we are part of the community-bulldozing force I and I hope many others want no part of enriching.

56.comment: I have come up with these idea to maximize safety. Currently downtown is very unsafe due to the rush of motor traffic on every street as well as no space for dogs to have a good run. I've notice dogs becoming more aggressive as they must live in apartments and when hey come out on the street it is chaotic and full of noise, sirens, and other unfamiliar dogs. I've seen several dog fights and attacks recently. Additionally, just a simple walk tot he grocery store is nerve wracking, due to motor traffic everywhere at high speeds. My suggestion is that high rise parking be built on one block where the freeways empty into downtown and people be required to park there and take shuttles into the city center. (Very common in most European cities). The emptied streets could then be planted up with green islands that people could actually use to walk, sit in, socialize, and some could be turned in dog runs. You cannot create pedestrian friendly space in a place where motor traffic dominates the area. it's that simple.

1.text: What color(s) would you want a tower at El Nudillo to be?

2.text: What artist(s) would you recommend to create artwork at El Nudillo?

3.text: How many crosswalks do you think a roundabout at El Nudillo should have?

4.text: Do you think people should be able to play in a fountain at El Nudillo? Why or why not?

6.text: Can we recommend art pieces to be installed in certain locations?

8.text: Is this available 24/7 to all people?

9.text: What will these towers be used for?

10.text: How would we look to implement a ban on auto traffic in this part of San Diego.

11.text: A double diamond interchange could fit into this intersection and allow for pedestrian and bikes. What do you think?

12.text: How do you envision residents accessing their homes?  What is the plan to protect pedestrians from bicycles and bikes and bike transport vehicles?  How can we raise the money in a reasonable period of time to implement the project before the momentum wears off?

13.text: How could the existing area be redesigned to meet the needs of everyone?

14.text: Should we instead install a monument?

15.text: How do we prevent homeless people from bathing in the fountain?

16.text: In an era when finding a place for those experiencing homelessness is incredibly difficult, why would we create an open plaza or park in lieu of a housing project?

17.text: What is your obsession with parks? I never see you at any of the other ones.

18.text: Why is this even under consideration? People literally sleep under the freeway every night, and you want a zipline? So selfish.

19.text: Why don't we let a culture develop in this area instead of trying to create one in a focus group?

20.text: What are the downsides of a roundabout?

21.text: Why are people obsessed with letting regular people produce art in the public right of way? What happened to aesthetics? Did modernism kill it?

22.text: How will this impact or improve the quality of life in both neighborhoods?

24.text: To all. How does your idea or ideas you support acknowledge, accommodate and enhance San Diego's diverse population? This area is teeming with people of color, and is part of the distinctly negative gentrifiying force affecting people of color. How are these communities engaged in this process? How will they benefit from this project-focus and force? What will they celebrate when they go home at night about their experience from this area? This note will likely ring a tiny bell in many that will be drowned out by the few in power.  But if we don't respect this perspective,  and decisively move from it,  then we are part of the community-bulldozing force I and I hope many others want no part of enriching.

26.text: How will you keep a park friendly to all? This area right now isn't visited due to its street living

28.text: I feel San Diego's sky line is very dark at night time; though it's slowly getting better. I travel a lot and love seeing buildings and skylines light up. What are your plans to make this beautiful building stand out at night time?

29.text: This would turn into another campground for the homeless.

30.text: How would an EV/Barrio Market impact living and working in your community?

31.text: What would be the benefit to the community for such a structure/concept?

32.text: Why would you want to adopt a solution that creates more division between the Barrio and the East Village.

33.text: What connections would best be supported by the concept. Bridges are only uses if they connect places that are not otherwise connected.

34.text: would this lessen your need to regularly use an automobile?

36.text: East Village Residents - are you going to keep your cars parked and use your feet or bike to take advantage of this?  Right now it seems like the only thing that gets attention is when it has drinking attached to it.

37.text: How do they envision celebrating this location of art? For viewing pleasure during travel, or for a place to visit/stay?

1.text: What color(s) would you want a tower at El Nudillo to be?

2.text: What artist(s) would you recommend to create artwork at El Nudillo?

3.text: How many crosswalks do you think a roundabout at El Nudillo should have?

4.text: Do you think people should be able to play in a fountain at El Nudillo? Why or why not?

6.text: Can we recommend art pieces to be installed in certain locations?

8.text: Is this available 24/7 to all people?

9.text: What will these towers be used for?

10.text: How would we look to implement a ban on auto traffic in this part of San Diego.

11.text: A double diamond interchange could fit into this intersection and allow for pedestrian and bikes. What do you think?

12.text: How do you envision residents accessing their homes?  What is the plan to protect pedestrians from bicycles and bikes and bike transport vehicles?  How can we raise the money in a reasonable period of time to implement the project before the momentum wears off?

13.text: How could the existing area be redesigned to meet the needs of everyone?

14.text: Should we instead install a monument?

15.text: How do we prevent homeless people from bathing in the fountain?

16.text: In an era when finding a place for those experiencing homelessness is incredibly difficult, why would we create an open plaza or park in lieu of a housing project?

17.text: What is your obsession with parks? I never see you at any of the other ones.

18.text: Why is this even under consideration? People literally sleep under the freeway every night, and you want a zipline? So selfish.

19.text: Why don't we let a culture develop in this area instead of trying to create one in a focus group?

20.text: What are the downsides of a roundabout?

21.text: Why are people obsessed with letting regular people produce art in the public right of way? What happened to aesthetics? Did modernism kill it?

22.text: How will this impact or improve the quality of life in both neighborhoods?

24.text: To all. How does your idea or ideas you support acknowledge, accommodate and enhance San Diego's diverse population? This area is teeming with people of color, and is part of the distinctly negative gentrifiying force affecting people of color. How are these communities engaged in this process? How will they benefit from this project-focus and force? What will they celebrate when they go home at night about their experience from this area? This note will likely ring a tiny bell in many that will be drowned out by the few in power.  But if we don't respect this perspective,  and decisively move from it,  then we are part of the community-bulldozing force I and I hope many others want no part of enriching.

26.text: How will you keep a park friendly to all? This area right now isn't visited due to its street living

28.text: I feel San Diego's sky line is very dark at night time; though it's slowly getting better. I travel a lot and love seeing buildings and skylines light up. What are your plans to make this beautiful building stand out at night time?

29.text: This would turn into another campground for the homeless.

30.text: How would an EV/Barrio Market impact living and working in your community?

31.text: What would be the benefit to the community for such a structure/concept?

32.text: Why would you want to adopt a solution that creates more division between the Barrio and the East Village.

33.text: What connections would best be supported by the concept. Bridges are only uses if they connect places that are not otherwise connected.

34.text: would this lessen your need to regularly use an automobile?

36.text: East Village Residents - are you going to keep your cars parked and use your feet or bike to take advantage of this?  Right now it seems like the only thing that gets attention is when it has drinking attached to it.

37.text: How do they envision celebrating this location of art? For viewing pleasure during travel, or for a place to visit/stay?

38.text: What about restricting only a portion of 14th street as a promenade (from K street to Commercial)? Cyclists should also be able to access this promenade, yes?

1.text: What color(s) would you want a tower at El Nudillo to be?

2.text: What artist(s) would you recommend to create artwork at El Nudillo?

3.text: How many crosswalks do you think a roundabout at El Nudillo should have?

4.text: Do you think people should be able to play in a fountain at El Nudillo? Why or why not?

6.text: Can we recommend art pieces to be installed in certain locations?

8.text: Is this available 24/7 to all people?

9.text: What will these towers be used for?

10.text: How would we look to implement a ban on auto traffic in this part of San Diego.

11.text: A double diamond interchange could fit into this intersection and allow for pedestrian and bikes. What do you think?

12.text: How do you envision residents accessing their homes?  What is the plan to protect pedestrians from bicycles and bikes and bike transport vehicles?  How can we raise the money in a reasonable period of time to implement the project before the momentum wears off?

13.text: How could the existing area be redesigned to meet the needs of everyone?

14.text: Should we instead install a monument?

15.text: How do we prevent homeless people from bathing in the fountain?

16.text: In an era when finding a place for those experiencing homelessness is incredibly difficult, why would we create an open plaza or park in lieu of a housing project?

17.text: What is your obsession with parks? I never see you at any of the other ones.

18.text: Why is this even under consideration? People literally sleep under the freeway every night, and you want a zipline? So selfish.

19.text: Why don't we let a culture develop in this area instead of trying to create one in a focus group?

20.text: What are the downsides of a roundabout?

21.text: Why are people obsessed with letting regular people produce art in the public right of way? What happened to aesthetics? Did modernism kill it?

22.text: How will this impact or improve the quality of life in both neighborhoods?

24.text: To all. How does your idea or ideas you support acknowledge, accommodate and enhance San Diego's diverse population? This area is teeming with people of color, and is part of the distinctly negative gentrifiying force affecting people of color. How are these communities engaged in this process? How will they benefit from this project-focus and force? What will they celebrate when they go home at night about their experience from this area? This note will likely ring a tiny bell in many that will be drowned out by the few in power.  But if we don't respect this perspective,  and decisively move from it,  then we are part of the community-bulldozing force I and I hope many others want no part of enriching.

33.text: What connections would best be supported by the concept. Bridges are only uses if they connect places that are not otherwise connected.

213.comment: The idea that San Diego is a city of neighborhoods is essential to the development of this particular site.  This juncture should not be seen in isolation, but as an opportunity to act as a catalyst to link neighborhoods.   It is not only a connector of neighborhoods, but also a transition point of one distinctly unique and cherished historical district (the Barrio) and another neighborhood also rich in history, but one more of transitions (East Village).  The link of these neighborhoods to Golden Hills and to Balboa Park is also essential to this idea.  The idea of the Nudillo should be one that can transform and be enriched over time.

295.comment: Creating a link between Barrio Logan and East Village is a necessity for the positive development of both neighborhoods.  The weekly market is a great idea and requires creating a large plaza area where this can be set up.  It could also serve as an outdoor performance area for locally based musicians, performers and artists.  Ongoing activities at this plaza would be required to keep it activated and of interest to the diverse population of the area.  Maybe a private industry promoter could be hired for this and also take over responsibility for activating Horton Plaza Park which Westfield has failed at.
